description: Grubtech is a unified commerce engine for Enterprise F&B, Grocery and Pharmaceutical Merchants using multiple online sales channels and back-end operations. Our main product, gOnline, connects all order sources to downstream systems like POS, ERP, Fleet Management, 3PLs, and Loyalty Programs. Our smart solutions help smoothen business operations and make the most of data for important decision making. Based in Dubai, Grubtech also has offices in Sri Lanka, Egypt, and Spain, serving customers in 18 markets.
description_enriched: Grubtech is an unified restaurant operations and management platform that connects restaurants with their systems to streamline operations and manage orders. They offer integration hubs for handling orders, managing menus, and streamlining operations effortlessly.

Feeling the frustration of dealing with bank transfers for new vendor payments? The time-consuming steps and delays can be a major hindrance to business productivity, impacting both Time and Money.

Recently, our team encountered a scenario where a simple bill payment of less than AED 5000 turned into an 8.5-hour ordeal involving a staggering 14 steps. This lengthy process resulted in a delay of 5 days for the service we required.

Qashio as a solution and a payment link would streamline this task to under a minute. By automating financial data entry, reconciliation, and integrating seamlessly with our Oracle NetSuite ERP system, the efficiency gains are significant. Not only would payments be expedited, but also rewards like Qashio points convertible to Emirates Skywards Miles would be earned.

Instead of spending 505 minutes navigating through multiple steps, including waiting for approvals, creating payments, and manual data entries, consider the impact on productivity and costs. The time wasted on these manual processes equates to more than a full day's salary.

By advocating for card payments with your vendors, you can minimize such inefficiencies and avoid absorbing unnecessary costs for processes that hinder your operations. Streamlining payment methods can save valuable time and resources, benefiting both your team and the business's bottom line. 

Here are the 14 steps and time it took to get the service delayed 5 days 
                                                                                            
1, Review the invoice                                                        - 5 min
2, Login to the banking portal and wait for the OTP   - 10 min
3, Wait for the banking page to load                              - 2 min
4, Upload the beneficiary                                                 - 7 min
5, Wait for the Authorizer to approve the beneficiary - 80 min
6, Authorizer to login and approve the beneficiary     - 15 min
7, COOLDOWN Period (for a adhoc transaction)        - 240 min
8, Create the payment (+ repeat step 1 - 3)                 - 24 min
9, Wait for Authorizer to release payment                     - 80 min
10, Authorizer to login, review and release payment   - 20 min
11, Create Vendor, Upload TRN in ERP system             - 20 min
12, Attach / Log TRN Number to claim VAT in ERP       - 4 min
13, Create Journal Voucher / Entry in ERP                      - 12 min
14, Double Check that manual entries are correct.      - 6 min                            

Work smarter with Qashio not harder with outdated processes...

Why I choose Deliveroo over talabat and why I shop on Amazon instead of noon.... for one simple reason - to EARN more miles, rewards, and points!

Whether you use credit cards for earning Marriott International Points, Emirates Skywards miles, or other benefits hinges on the "interchange" or in other words the commission provided to the card provider by the payment gateway that the merchants use. This commission is determined by the Merchant Category Code (MCC), which is a percentage of the transaction value determined by the category the merchant belongs to.

For instance, Deliveroo is rightfully categorized as a restaurant, while Talabat is classified as a grocery company despite primarily focusing on aggregating restaurant deliveries and claiming they are a technology company on their Linkedin page. Similarly, Noon, markets itself as an E-commerce or Retail entity (according to their Linkedin page in UAE & KSA) while their MCC carries a grocery status. These companies collaborate with payment gateways to lower fees, resulting in reduced rewards for their customers like miles and cashbacks on credit cards used.

This practice extends beyond just these examples. To optimize spending and maximize rewards, it's crucial to choose vendors wisely.

Both Noon & Talabat are otherwise great services and great companies with fantastic individuals leading the organizations employing some of the best talent in the country. I would have used them much more frequently if I would have earned the same rewards on my credit cards as I do when using Deliveroo and Amazon since the cost to me remains the same.
